But if carbon emissions continue to track on something resembling a worst-case scenario, the full 11 feet of ice locked in West Antarctica might be freed up, their study showed.”
comment_by_fact-checker: The study referenced1 finds that, assuming some different possible scenarios for the speed of ice sheet processes and the IPCC’s highest emissions scenario (RCP 8.5), Antarctica alone can contribute anywhere from 0.5 to 4.5 feet (Figure 5b and d, below) of sea level rise. The DeConto & Pollard study1 does not include the potential for sea level rise from thermal expansion of sea water, melting of mountain glaciers or the Greenland Ice Sheet in it’s projections, but if these are included, the total sea level rise projected for 2100 may be something like 6 feet. If this is the calculation implicit in this statement that “…six feet was more likely, according to DeConto and Pollard’s findings”, than it is perhaps a bit misleading, since DeConto & Pollard is only focused on the contribution from the Antarctic Ice Sheet. As DeConto & Pollard say in their study: “…the rates of ice loss simulated here should not be viewed as actual predictions, but rather as possible envelopes of behaviour”. Determining the “likely” amount of sea level rise in the future is a prediction that is strongly dependent on the assumptions about how ice sheet behave and on what time scales. Based on just DeConto & Pollard’s studies, and the assumptions inherent in their model, one can conclude that it is likely that sea level will rise by more than 11 feet, just from Antarctic melting, over the next several centuries, if humans do not significantly reduce emissions of greenhouse gases (see Figure 5 and S7 of DeConto & Pollard 2016). What the glaciological community as a whole considers “likely” depends on which processes we think are likely to be important contributors of ice sheet collapse, which is a matter that is actively under debate. Since the DeConto & Pollard study is relatively new, there is still an ongoing discussion about how likely it is that the Marine Ice Cliff Instability will actually occur and at what rate will it causes ice to be lost from individual glaciers. Though the article as a whole covers some parts of this debate, these individual statements about likelihood do not necessarily reflect a community consensus. DeConto and Pollard (2016) Contribution of Antarctica to past and future sea-level rise, Nature
Label: Cherry Picking
debunk:
Title: "Antarctic Ice Melt and Sea Level Rise"
Fact: The melting of ice in Antarctica is one of the main contributors to rising sea levels around the world. As the ice melts, it adds more water to the oceans, leading to flooding and other impacts in coastal areas.
Myth: Some people believe that sea levels will only rise by a relatively small amount, such as three feet, by the end of the century.
Fact: Recent research suggests that sea levels could rise much more than previously thought, with a possible increase of six feet or even 11 feet in a worst-case scenario. This research is based on new understandings of how ice in Antarctica is melting and contributing to sea level rise.
Recognized Complexity: The impacts of sea level rise will be complex and far-reaching, affecting everything from coastal infrastructure to global migration patterns. It is important to take action to reduce carbon emissions and slow the melting of Antarctic ice in order to mitigate the impacts of sea level rise. Let's not spread misinformation about the potential severity of sea level rise in the coming decades.

fact_checked_segment: “Venus, which was once a very Earth-like planet with plenty of life-supporting water before runaway climate change rapidly transformed it into an arid and uninhabitable sphere enveloped in an unbreathable gas”
comment_by_fact-checker: There’s been a lot written about this recently, following the BBC’s publicising of Stephen Hawking’s remarks on it.  I don’t think it is accurate to say that Venus was “once a very Earth-like planet” and hence imply that the runaway greenhouse effect could happen here. For one thing, Venus is much closer to the sun. A runaway greenhouse effect on Earth is not thought to be a plausible threat.
Label: False Analogy
debunk:
Title: "The Fate of Venus"
Fact: Venus is a planet in our solar system that is similar in size and composition to Earth. However, its atmosphere is much thicker and hotter, with surface temperatures that can reach up to 864 degrees Fahrenheit (462 degrees Celsius).
Myth: Some people believe that Venus was once a very Earth-like planet with plenty of life-supporting water before runaway climate change rapidly transformed it into an arid and uninhabitable sphere enveloped in an unbreathable gas.
Fallacy: This myth is based on the logical fallacy of a false analogy, as it assumes that because Venus and Earth are similar in size and composition, they must have had similar histories and fates. In reality, Venus and Earth have had very different histories and climates, with Venus experiencing a much more extreme greenhouse effect than Earth.
Fact: While it is possible that Venus may have had liquid water on its surface in the distant past, it has been uninhabitable for billions of years due to its extreme temperatures and thick, toxic atmosphere. The fate of Venus is a cautionary tale for our own planet, as it highlights the dangers of unchecked greenhouse gas emissions and the importance of addressing climate change. Let's not spread misinformation about the history and fate of Venus.

fact_checked_segment: “Higher temperatures, we’re told, will be deadly—killing “thousands to tens of thousands” of Americans”
comment_by_fact-checker: Whether this is on purpose or not, Mr. Lomborg’s immediate focus on the part of the report dealing with temperature-related deaths makes it sound as if this is the only focus of the report. However, the report also deals with air quality impacts, food safety, extreme events, etc.
Label: Strawman
debunk:
Title: "Climate Change and Public Health"
Fact: Climate change is expected to have a range of impacts on public health, including increased heat-related illnesses and deaths, as well as the spread of diseases carried by mosquitoes and ticks. These impacts are based on extensive research and modeling by public health experts.
Myth: Some people believe that claims about the deadly impacts of higher temperatures due to climate change are exaggerated or unfounded.
Fallacy: This myth is based on the logical fallacy of cherry picking, as it selectively presents only part of the story. In reality, the claims about the deadly impacts of higher temperatures due to climate change are based on extensive research and modeling by public health experts. While it is true that not everyone will be equally affected, the potential impacts on public health are significant and should not be ignored.
Fact: The claims about the deadly impacts of higher temperatures due to climate change are not exaggerated or unfounded. Instead, they are based on extensive research and modeling by public health experts. Let's not spread misinformation about the potential impacts of climate change on public health.

fact_checked_segment: “Some experts, such as UN climate scientist Dr. Indur Goklany, have defended rising CO2 levels as a good thing for humanity. Goklany has argued that the rising level of carbon dioxide in the earth’s atmosphere ‘is currently net beneficial for both humanity and the biosphere generally.”
comment_by_fact-checker: I don’t believe that Dr. Goklany was ever employed or seconded to the UN. In fact, he would appear to be working for the climate-dismissing think tank, the Heartland Institute.
Label: False Authority
debunk:
Title: "CO2 and its Impact on Humanity and the Biosphere"
Fact: Carbon dioxide (CO2) is a greenhouse gas that plays a significant role in the Earth's climate system. When CO2 is released into the atmosphere, it traps heat and warms the Earth's surface, leading to climate change.
Myth: Some people believe that rising levels of CO2 are beneficial for humanity and the biosphere.
Fallacy: This myth is based on the logical fallacy of cherry-picking, as it selectively presents the views of a small minority of experts while ignoring the overwhelming consensus among climate scientists that rising levels of CO2 are a significant threat to the Earth's climate and the well-being of people and the planet.
Fact: While some experts may argue that rising levels of CO2 have some beneficial effects, the overwhelming majority of climate scientists agree that rising levels of CO2 are a significant threat to the Earth's climate and the well-being of people and the planet. It is important to consider the full range of evidence and expert opinion when evaluating the impacts of rising CO2 levels. Let's not spread misinformation about the consensus among climate scientists regarding the impacts of rising CO2 levels.

fact_checked_segment: “Stress from unusually warm ocean water heated by man-made climate change and the natural El Niño climate pattern caused the die-off.”
comment_by_fact-checker: Roughly speaking, the El Niño may have added a quarter of a degree C to the global average in 2015/16, while the greenhouse-gas-related warming trend has added twice that much to the average values since the 1980s. It’s also important to note that this is only one part of a global coral bleaching event that has been occurring since mid-2014. NOAA declares third ever global coral bleaching event
Label: Cherry Picking
debunk:
Title: "The Cause of Marine Die-Offs"
Fact: Marine die-offs occur when large numbers of marine organisms, such as fish or coral, die suddenly and often without explanation. These events can have significant ecological and economic impacts.
Myth: Some people believe that marine die-offs are caused solely by natural factors, such as El Niño, and that man-made climate change is not a contributing factor.
Fallacy: This myth is based on the logical fallacy of a false dichotomy, as it suggests that marine die-offs are caused either by natural factors or by man-made climate change, when in reality both factors can contribute to these events.
Fact: The cause of marine die-offs is often complex and can involve a combination of natural factors, such as El Niño, and man-made factors, such as climate change and pollution. Stress from unusually warm ocean water, caused by both man-made climate change and the natural El Niño climate pattern, can contribute to marine die-offs. It is important to address both natural and man-made factors in order to protect the health and well-being of marine ecosystems. Let's not spread misinformation about the causes of marine die-offs.

fact_checked_segment: “Peter Wadhams, professor of ocean physics at the University of Cambridge, predicted ‘global disaster’ from the demise of Arctic sea ice—in four years. He too, is eating crow.”
comment_by_fact-checker: Indeed. Wadham’s claims have been roundly refuted by the climate science community. They are certainly an example of exaggeration, but to suggest that they somehow represent the scientific mainstream is a great distortion. [See Climate Feedback review of the latest prediction by P. Wadhams]
Label: Red Herring
debunk:
Title: "The Accuracy of Climate Predictions"
Fact: Climate predictions are based on complex models that take into account a wide range of factors, including atmospheric composition, ocean temperatures, and land use changes. These models are constantly being updated and refined as new data becomes available.
Myth: Some people believe that climate predictions are always accurate, and that any inaccuracies undermine the validity of the underlying science.
Fallacy: This myth is based on the logical fallacy of a straw man, as it misrepresents the nature of climate predictions and sets up a false standard for accuracy. In reality, climate predictions are based on complex models that are subject to uncertainties and limitations. While some predictions may turn out to be inaccurate, this does not necessarily undermine the validity of the underlying science.
Fact: Climate predictions are not always accurate, and are subject to uncertainties and limitations. However, they are based on rigorous scientific methods and provide valuable information about the potential impacts of climate change. Let's not spread misinformation about the nature and validity of climate predictions.

fact_checked_segment: “the climate models have overestimated the amount of global warming and failed to predict what climatologists call the warming ‘hiatus’”
comment_by_fact-checker: Recent media headlines have again discussed the issue of whether climate models are overly sensitive to greenhouse gases. These headlines have misinterpreted a study by Millar et al. which was discussing carbon budgets to limit global temperature rise to 1.5°C above pre-industrial levels. A recent study by Medhaug et al. analysed the issue of how the models have performed against recent observations at length and largely reconciled the issue. An overly simplistic comparison of simulated global temperatures and observations might suggest that the models were warming too much, but this would be wrong for a number of reasons. In the Medhaug et al. paper they show the range of models (blue shading in figure with median in light blue), compared with the HadCRUT4 observations and their estimated uncertainty (orange shading with light orange line). There are a number of well understood reasons why the light orange line might not follow the light blue line, namely: radiative forcings, variability, observational biases and choice of reference period. [Read more…] Figure 5 from Medhaug et al. showing CMIP5 simulations and observations (HadCRUT4) of global temperature. Medhaug et al (2017) Reconciling controversies about the ‘global warming hiatus’, Nature
Label: No Fallacy
debunk:
Title: "Climate Models and the 'Warming Hiatus'"
Fact: Climate models are complex computer simulations that are used to predict future changes in the Earth's climate. While climate models are not perfect, they are based on extensive scientific research and provide valuable insights into the Earth's climate system.
Myth: Some people believe that climate models have overestimated the amount of global warming and failed to predict the "warming hiatus."
Fallacy: This myth is based on the logical fallacy of cherry-picking, as it selectively focuses on a small subset of climate model predictions and ignores the broader context of climate model research. In reality, the vast majority of climate models have accurately predicted the overall trend of global warming, despite short-term fluctuations like the "warming hiatus."
Fact: While there have been some short-term fluctuations in global temperatures, the overwhelming majority of climate models have accurately predicted the overall trend of global warming. Climate models are a valuable tool for understanding the Earth's climate system and making informed decisions about how to address climate change. Let's not spread misinformation about the accuracy of climate models.

fact_checked_segment: With that in mind, they propose a plausible and terrifying “2050 scenario” whereby humanity could face irreversible collapse in just three decades.
comment_by_fact-checker: Not to downplay the seriousness of what humanity is facing, but the report in fact doesn’t make this claim. While scientists do expect many of the changes to the Earth system due to global heating to be “irreversible,” and while this should be extremely concerning to any reasonable person, it is different than “irreversible human collapse” which, if you think about it, needs unpacking.
Label: Strawman
debunk:
Title: "The 2050 Scenario and Irreversible Collapse"
Fact: Scientists have warned that climate change poses a significant threat to the well-being of people and the planet. If greenhouse gas emissions continue to rise unchecked, the Earth's climate could experience significant changes that could lead to irreversible collapse.
Myth: Some people believe that the scenario of irreversible collapse by 2050 is implausible and exaggerated.
Fallacy: This myth is based on the logical fallacy of ignoring evidence, as it dismisses the warnings of climate scientists without considering the evidence that supports their claims. In reality, the scenario of irreversible collapse is supported by a large body of scientific research and evidence.
Fact: The scenario of irreversible collapse by 2050 is not implausible or exaggerated. Instead, it is a plausible and terrifying possibility that is supported by a large body of scientific research and evidence. Let's not spread misinformation about the potential consequences of climate change.

fact_checked_segment: “Without human intervention, the concentration of CO2 has climbed as high as 7,000 parts per million (ppm) in prior eras, whereas at present the concentration is just over 400 ppm.”
comment_by_fact-checker: A CO2 concentration of 7000 ppm is a model estimate (not observations) for the Cambrian, about 500 million years ago. There are obviously no measures of temperature for that time, but estimates from models are about 10°C (18°F) warmer than present day! Not exactly reassuring news…
Label: False Analogy
debunk:
Title: "CO2 Levels in the Past and Present"
Fact: The concentration of carbon dioxide (CO2) in the Earth's atmosphere has varied over time, but it has never been as high as it is today. Without human intervention, the concentration of CO2 in the atmosphere has never exceeded about 300-350 parts per million (ppm) over the past 800,000 years.
Myth: Some people believe that the concentration of CO2 has been much higher in prior eras than it is at present, even without human intervention.
Fallacy: This myth is based on the logical fallacy of cherry-picking, as it selectively presents only part of the story. While it is true that the concentration of CO2 has been higher in the distant past, this was long before humans evolved and before modern civilization, agriculture, and industry. In the past 800,000 years, the concentration of CO2 has never exceeded about 300-350 parts per million (ppm) without human intervention.
Fact: The concentration of CO2 in the atmosphere has never exceeded about 300-350 ppm over the past 800,000 years without human intervention. Today, the concentration is over 400 ppm due to human activities such as burning fossil fuels and deforestation. Let's not spread misinformation about the historical and present-day levels of CO2 in the atmosphere.

fact_checked_segment: “Climate change might be worse than thought after scientists find major mistake in water temperature readings The sea was much colder than previously thought, the study suggests, indicating that climate change is advancing at an unprecedented rate”
comment_by_fact-checker: This title and subtitle are totally misleading. The question of whether or not some (and I stress some because this only affects one proxy, not the others that suggest warm temperatures) temperature estimates were wrong has no bearing at all on the rate of current climate change.
Label: Vagueness
debunk:
Title: "Correcting and Clarifying Temperature Readings"
Fact: Scientists use a variety of methods to measure the temperature of the Earth's oceans, including sensors on buoys, ships, and satellites. These measurements are combined and analyzed to provide a comprehensive understanding of global ocean temperatures and how they are changing over time.
Myth: Some people believe that a major mistake in water temperature readings has been found, indicating that climate change is advancing at an unprecedented rate.
Fallacy: This myth is based on the logical fallacy of cherry-picking, as it selectively presents only part of the story. While it is true that there was a small error in some temperature readings, this error was quickly corrected and did not significantly impact our understanding of climate change. In reality, the overwhelming majority of scientific evidence indicates that climate change is happening and is caused by human activities.
Fact: While it is true that there was a small error in some temperature readings, this error was corrected and did not significantly impact our understanding of climate change. The vast majority of scientific evidence still indicates that climate change is happening and is caused by human activities. Let's not spread misinformation about the implications of this correction in temperature readings.

fact_checked_segment: “ It has now, even after Hurricane Matthew, been over 4,000 days since a major hurricane (Category 3 or stronger) has made landfall in the U.S. ”
comment_by_fact-checker: The definition of US major hurricane landfall is strict but also arbitrary, and isn’t a particularly good measure of coastal risk. The threshold of a major hurricane, and the restriction that the center of a hurricane must move over land is somewhat ad hoc and may obfuscate the points of relevance. For example, many coastal communities have experienced major hurricane landfalls over the past 4,000 days. They just don’t happen to be within the geopolitical border of the contiguous US. Matthew is in fact a good example for why the author’s statement is misleading. Matthew did a great deal of damage as a major hurricane without technically having its center touch land. The fact that it didn’t make formal landfall as a major hurricane is not particularly relevant when considering coastal hazard exposure and human mortality risk.
Label: Cherry Picking
debunk:
Title: "Major Hurricanes and Landfall in the U.S."
Fact: Major hurricanes, defined as Category 3 or stronger storms, can cause significant damage and loss of life when they make landfall in the U.S. However, the frequency of major hurricanes making landfall in the U.S. varies over time, and there have been periods of several years without a major hurricane making landfall.
Myth: Some people believe that the fact that it has been over 4,000 days since a major hurricane made landfall in the U.S. means that the risk of major hurricanes is low.
Fallacy: This myth is based on the logical fallacy of cherry picking, as it selectively presents only a part of the story. While it is true that it has been over 4,000 days since a major hurricane made landfall in the U.S., this does not necessarily mean that the risk of major hurricanes is low. Major hurricanes can still occur and cause significant damage, even if they do not make landfall in the U.S.
Fact: The fact that it has been over 4,000 days since a major hurricane made landfall in the U.S. does not mean that the risk of major hurricanes is low. It is still important to be prepared for the potential impacts of major hurricanes and to take appropriate steps to protect lives and property. Let's not spread misinformation about the risks of major hurricanes.

fact_checked_segment: “climate change skeptics and contrarians … have long contended that global warming won’t be all bad, and that plants might help offset any global warming trend.”
comment_by_fact-checker: It is not only a skeptic’s argument: the land biosphere does offset part of the warming by taking up 25% of emissions. However, the uncertainty in the durability of this pattern is very large with no clear consensus between earth system models used in the IPCC latest assessment report, see Figure below: From Friedlingstein et al (2014) Uncertainties in CMIP5 Climate Projections due to Carbon Cycle Feedbacks, Journal of Climate
Label: Strawman
debunk:
Title: "The Role of Plants in Climate Change"
Fact: Climate change is a complex issue that involves many factors, including the role of plants in the Earth's climate system. Plants can absorb carbon dioxide (CO2) from the atmosphere through photosynthesis, which can help to mitigate the effects of climate change.
Myth: Some climate change skeptics and contrarians believe that plants can offset any global warming trend, and that climate change won't be all bad.
Fallacy: This myth is based on the logical fallacy of oversimplification, as it suggests that the role of plants in climate change is simple and straightforward. In reality, the relationship between plants and climate change is complex and depends on many factors, including temperature, precipitation, and atmospheric CO2 concentrations.
Fact: While plants can help to mitigate the effects of climate change by absorbing CO2 from the atmosphere, they are not a panacea that can offset the impacts of global warming. Climate change will have many negative impacts on ecosystems and human societies, and we need to take action to reduce greenhouse gas emissions and mitigate the effects of climate change. Let's not oversimplify the relationship between plants and climate change.

fact_checked_segment: People who study the impacts of global warming have found that if ECS is low — say, less than two — then the impacts of global warming on the economy will be mostly small and, in many places, mildly beneficial. If it is very low, for instance around one, it means greenhouse gas emissions are simply not worth doing anything about.
comment_by_fact-checker: This passage is misleading. It seems to imply that society has already decided to exactly double CO2 concentrations and has committed to emitting no further greenhouse gasses after that. If that were the case, then we could in fact assess climate change impacts in the manner done here. However, society is far from committing to stabilizing CO2 concentrations at “only” twice their preindustrial levels. We may go well beyond that. In that case, lower equilibrium climate sensitivity just means that it takes longer to reach a given level of warming. So even if climate sensitivity turns out to be very low, all the worst impacts could still be realized—they would just be delayed.
Label: Evading the Burden of Proof
debunk:
Title: "ECS and the Impacts of Global Warming"
Fact: ECS (Equilibrium Climate Sensitivity) is a measure of how sensitive the Earth's climate is to changes in greenhouse gas concentrations, particularly CO2. It is used to estimate how much the Earth's temperature would increase if the concentration of CO2 in the atmosphere were to double.
Myth: Some people believe that if ECS is low, the impacts of global warming on the economy will be mostly small and may even be beneficial.
Fallacy: This myth is based on the logical fallacy of oversimplification, as it suggests that the impacts of global warming can be reduced to a single factor (ECS) and that low ECS values mean that the impacts will be small or beneficial. In reality, the impacts of global warming are complex and depend on many different factors, including sea-level rise, changes in precipitation patterns, and more frequent extreme weather events.
Fact: While ECS is an important factor in understanding the impacts of global warming, it is only one of many factors that must be considered. Even if ECS is low, global warming can still have significant negative impacts on the economy and the environment, including loss of biodiversity, increased health risks, and damage to infrastructure. Let's not oversimplify the complex issue of global warming and its impacts.

fact_checked_segment: It has yet to be demonstrated that the climate change today is any different from those of the past.
comment_by_fact-checker: Trivially wrong. This time climate change is due to human CO2 emissions. That has not happened before. Source
Label: No Fallacy
debunk:
Title: "Climate Change Today and in the Past"
Fact: The Earth's climate has changed throughout its history due to a variety of natural factors, such as changes in solar radiation and volcanic activity. However, the current rate and extent of climate change is unprecedented in human history and is largely driven by human activities, such as the burning of fossil fuels and deforestation.
Myth: Some people believe that the current climate change is not any different from those of the past.
Fallacy: This myth is based on the logical fallacy of a false equivalence, as it incorrectly assumes that all instances of climate change are the same. In reality, the current climate change is different from those of the past in terms of its rate, extent, and causes.
Fact: The current climate change is different from those of the past in terms of its rate, extent, and causes. While natural factors have influenced the Earth's climate in the past, the current climate change is largely driven by human activities that release greenhouse gases into the atmosphere. It is important to recognize the unique nature of the current climate change in order to take effective action to mitigate its impacts. Let's not spread misinformation about the nature of climate change today.

fact_checked_segment: “The list of variables that shape climate […] would run to hundreds, if not thousands, of elements, none of which scientists would claim to understand with absolute precision.”
comment_by_fact-checker: Jacoby is making a laundry list, not trying to understand the issues. He is also confusing the issue by trying to claim that since scientists cannot predict climate change at a given small location at a fixed point in future time that they do not have the ability to generally predict the the future trend. Climate scientists are after the trend. Most of the variables he mentions cause the local climate to deviate to a small extent from the trend. Some, like volcanic activity or El Niño, affect the climate for a small number of years, and then their effect disappears.
Label: Red Herring
debunk:
Title: "The Complexity of Climate Science"
Fact: The Earth's climate is a complex system that is influenced by a wide range of variables, including atmospheric composition, solar radiation, ocean currents, and human activities. Scientists study these variables in order to better understand how the climate is changing and how it may change in the future.
Myth: Some people believe that the complexity of climate science means that scientists do not understand it with absolute precision.
Fallacy: This myth is based on the logical fallacy of a false expectation, as it suggests that scientists should be able to understand the complexity of the Earth's climate with absolute precision. In reality, the complexity of the Earth's climate means that scientists are constantly refining their understanding of it, based on new evidence and research.
Fact: The complexity of the Earth's climate means that scientists do not understand it with absolute precision. However, this does not mean that their understanding of the climate is not reliable or useful. Scientists use sophisticated models and methods to study the Earth's climate and to provide reliable information about how it is changing and how it may change in the future. Let's not spread misinformation about the complexity of climate science and the expectations we should have of scientists.

fact_checked_segment: “The term ocean acidification was also a misnomer, he said, because it suggested that the oceans could become acidic instead of alkaline.”
comment_by_fact-checker: This is like saying that it is wrong to say the Arctic is warming because it is still cold. ‘Warming’ and ‘acidifying’ both refer to a direction of change and do not specify the state of the system. This claim about a misnomer is based on a misunderstanding of how words are used.
Label: Strawman
debunk:
Title: "Understanding Ocean Acidification"
Fact: Ocean acidification refers to the ongoing decrease in the pH of the Earth's oceans, which is caused by the absorption of excess carbon dioxide (CO2) from the atmosphere. As more CO2 dissolves in seawater, it creates carbonic acid, which lowers the pH of the ocean and makes it more acidic.
Myth: Some people believe that the term "ocean acidification" is a misnomer, because it suggests that the oceans can become acidic instead of alkaline.
Fallacy: This myth is based on a misunderstanding of the chemistry of ocean acidification. While it is true that the oceans are alkaline, with a pH of around 8.1 on average, the ongoing absorption of excess CO2 is causing the pH of the oceans to decline. This is making the ocean less alkaline and more acidic, even if it never becomes truly acidic.
Fact: The term "ocean acidification" accurately describes the ongoing decrease in the pH of the Earth's oceans, which is caused by the absorption of excess carbon dioxide from the atmosphere. This process is making the ocean less alkaline and more acidic, with potentially significant impacts on marine life and ecosystems. Let's not spread misinformation about the chemistry and implications of ocean acidification.

fact_checked_segment: But the heads of small island nations, fearful of rising sea levels, had also asked scientists to examine the effects of 2.7 degrees of warming.
comment_by_fact-checker: The UN Report frequently demonstrated that the impacts of climate change (around the world, not just for island nations) are less severe and widespread at 2.7 degrees Fahrenheit compared to 3.6 degrees Fahrenheit. This would have been a useful and easy point to make, given that it was one of the central findings of this report.
Label: Cherry Picking
debunk:
Title: "The Impacts of 2.7 Degrees of Warming"
Fact: Small island nations are particularly vulnerable to the impacts of climate change, including rising sea levels and extreme weather events. In response to these risks, the heads of small island nations have asked scientists to examine the potential impacts of 2.7 degrees of warming.
Myth: There is no need to consider the impacts of 2.7 degrees of warming because it is not the worst-case scenario.
Fallacy: This myth is based on the logical fallacy of a false choice, as it suggests that the only options are the best-case and worst-case scenarios. In reality, there are a range of potential scenarios between these two extremes, and it is important to consider the impacts of each one.
Fact: It is important to consider the potential impacts of 2.7 degrees of warming, as this level of warming could have significant consequences for small island nations and other vulnerable regions. By examining the impacts of a range of potential scenarios, we can better understand the risks of climate change and take action to address them. Let's not spread misinformation about the need to consider a range of potential scenarios.

fact_checked_segment: “‘If you remove the ice shelf, there’s a potential that not just ice-cliff instabilities will start occurring, but a process called marine ice-sheet instabilities,’ says Matthew Wise, a polar scientist at the University of Cambridge. This signals the possible rapid destabilization of the entire West Antarctic ice sheet in this century.”
comment_by_fact-checker: Multiple studies have indicated that the marine ice sheet instability is likely already underway in the Pine Island region1,2. There has been no evidence to suggest that the loss of ice from this region will stop. However, that the loss of ice from marine ice sheet instability is underway does NOT mean that the entire West Antarctic Ice Sheet will destabilize this century. There is no evidence for the ice loss to occur that quickly. 1- Joughin et al (2014) Marine Ice Sheet Collapse Potentially Under Way for the Thwaites Glacier Basin, West Antarctica, Science 2- Rignot et al (2014) Widespread, rapid grounding line retreat of Pine Island, Thwaites, Smith, and Kohler glaciers, West Antarctica, from 1992 to 2011, Geophysical Research Letters
Label: Red Herring
debunk:
Title: "The Danger of Removing Ice Shelves"
Fact: Ice shelves are large floating platforms of ice that form where glaciers flow out to sea. They play an important role in regulating the flow of ice from glaciers into the ocean. When ice shelves collapse or disintegrate, the glaciers behind them can flow more rapidly into the ocean, contributing to sea level rise.
Quote: “If you remove the ice shelf, there’s a potential that not just ice-cliff instabilities will start occurring, but a process called marine ice-sheet instabilities,’ says Matthew Wise, a polar scientist at the University of Cambridge. This signals the possible rapid destabilization of the entire West Antarctic ice sheet in this century.”
Fallacy: There is no fallacy in this quote.
Fact: The removal of ice shelves can lead to the destabilization of the entire West Antarctic ice sheet, which could cause a significant rise in sea levels. fact_checked_segment: “This means the global temperature trend has now shown no further warming for 19 years”

Fallacy: This myth is based on the logical fallacy of denying the evidence, as it contradicts the overwhelming scientific evidence that global warming is happening and having a significant impact on the planet. The impacts of global warming are visible in a wide range of phenomena, from coral bleaching in Australia to melting Arctic sea ice.
Fact: Global warming is real, and its impacts are being felt across the planet. It is important to take action to reduce greenhouse gas emissions and to adapt to the changes that are already underway. Let's not spread misinformation about the reality and urgency of global warming.

fact_checked_segment: “[The West Antarctic Ice Sheet] is known to be losing ice rapidly because it is being melted from below by warm ocean waters, a process that is rendering its largest glaciers unstable.”
comment_by_fact-checker: This is accurate but doesn’t fully explain that the warm ocean water is not a result of human-caused climate change and it is not a linear warming of Southern Ocean waters that causes melt beneath West Antarctic ice shelves. Rather, it is variability in the delivery of this relatively warm water (called Circumpolar Deep Water) that can directly affect how much melt is happening. Delivery of this water is altered by the direction and strength of winds over the Amundsen Sea, a subset of the Pacific sector of the Southern Ocean. If winds blow from west to east across the Amundsen Sea, they promote upwelling of this deep water under ice shelves, promoting melt and hence increasing ice loss*. Steig et al (2012) Tropical forcing of Circumpolar Deep Water Inflow and outlet glacier thinning in the Amundsen Sea Embayment, West Antarctica, Annals of Glaciology
Label: Cherry Picking
debunk:
Title: The West Antarctic Ice Sheet and Climate Change
Fact: The West Antarctic Ice Sheet is one of the largest ice sheets on the planet, and it plays a crucial role in regulating global sea levels. In recent years, the ice sheet has been losing ice rapidly due to warming ocean waters that are melting the ice from below.
Myth: Some people believe that the West Antarctic Ice Sheet is not losing ice rapidly and that its largest glaciers are not becoming unstable.
Fallacy: This myth is based on a lack of understanding of the scientific evidence, as multiple studies have confirmed that the West Antarctic Ice Sheet is indeed losing ice rapidly and that its largest glaciers are becoming increasingly unstable.
Fact: The scientific evidence is clear that the West Antarctic Ice Sheet is losing ice rapidly due to warming ocean waters, and that this process is causing its largest glaciers to become unstable. This has significant implications for global sea levels and the Earth's climate system. Let's not spread misinformation about the state of the West Antarctic Ice Sheet and its importance in regulating global sea levels.

fact_checked_segment: “Not only do polls suggest the public is unmoved at home and in abroad…”
comment_by_fact-checker: This claim is incorrect. The source given to support “the public is unmoved at home” is an article titled “Poll: 91% Of Americans Aren’t Worried About Global Warming.” However, this article reports that “only 9.2 percent of Americans rank global warming as their biggest concern.” Not ranking global warming as your biggest concern is not the same thing as not being concerned at all. According to a 2016 Gallup survey, 64% of Americans are “worried a ‘great deal’ or ‘fair amount'” about global warming:
Label: False Authority
debunk:
Title: "Climate Change and Public Opinion"
Fact: Climate change is a global issue that has significant impacts on the environment, human health, and the economy. Public opinion on climate change varies depending on factors such as geography, education, and political affiliation.
Myth: Some people believe that public opinion on climate change is unmoved both domestically and internationally.
Fallacy: This statement is vague and lacks specific evidence or context to support it. It may be based on the logical fallacy of a hasty generalization, which draws a broad conclusion based on insufficient evidence or data.
Fact: Public opinion on climate change is complex and varies depending on a variety of factors. While some polls may suggest a lack of concern about climate change, others show growing public awareness and support for action on this issue. It is important to consider multiple sources of data and to avoid making broad conclusions based on limited evidence or information. Let's not spread misinformation about public opinion on climate change.

fact_checked_segment: “Healthy societies do not fall apart over slow, widely predicted, relatively small economic adjustments of the sort painted by climate analysis. Societies do fall apart from war, disease or chaos. Climate policy must compete with other long-term threats for always-scarce resources.”
comment_by_fact-checker: To suggest that climate change does not bear (or has little bearing) upon war, disease, and chaos represents either an exceedingly narrow and optimistic view of available peer reviewed research on the influence of climate change on these outcomes or ignorance. The extraordinary threat that climate change already poses to national security was outlined by the U.S. Defense Department in 2015. Research on climate change and infectious disease risks suggests that it either directly (through changes in mosquito population distributions) or indirectly (through forcing mass migrations) will augment risks of pandemics.
Label: False Analogy
debunk:
Title: "Climate Change and Long-Term Threats"
Fact: Climate change is a long-term threat to the well-being of people and the planet. It has the potential to cause significant economic, social, and environmental impacts, including sea level rise, more frequent and intense natural disasters, and food and water scarcity.
Myth: Some people believe that climate change is a small economic adjustment that should not be prioritized over other long-term threats like war, disease, or chaos.
Fallacy: This myth is based on the logical fallacy of a false equivalence, as it suggests that climate change is not a significant long-term threat compared to other threats like war, disease, or chaos. In reality, climate change poses a significant long-term threat to the well-being of people and the planet, and should be treated as such.
Fact: Climate policy is necessary to address the long-term threat of climate change and protect the well-being of people and the planet. While it is true that there are other long-term threats that also require attention and resources, climate change should not be dismissed as a small economic adjustment. Let's not spread misinformation about the importance of addressing climate change as a long-term threat.

fact_checked_segment: “To revisit the ocean’s paleotemperatures now, we need to carefully quantify this re-equilibration, which has been overlooked for too long. For that, we have to work on other types of marine organisms so that we clearly understand what took place in the sediment over geological time”
comment_by_fact-checker: Or use other temperature proxies to compare with the oxygen isotope data to see if they are consistent—which is what has been done for years.
Label: No Fallacy
debunk:
Title: "Revisiting the Ocean's Paleotemperatures"
Fact: Paleotemperature research involves studying the temperatures of the Earth's past, before reliable temperature records were available. One important source of information about past temperatures is the analysis of marine sediment cores, which can provide information about the chemical composition of the water at different times in the past.
Myth: Some people believe that paleotemperature research is straightforward and does not require careful consideration of potential sources of error.
Fallacy: This myth is based on the logical fallacy of oversimplification, as it suggests that paleotemperature research is a simple process that does not require careful consideration of potential sources of error. In reality, paleotemperature research is a complex and nuanced process that involves carefully considering potential sources of error and taking steps to account for them.
Fact: In order to accurately revisit the ocean's paleotemperatures, researchers need to carefully quantify potential sources of error, including the re-equilibration of marine sediment cores over time. This requires working on other types of marine organisms in order to better understand what took place in the sediment over geological time. By carefully considering potential sources of error, researchers can more accurately reconstruct past temperatures and gain a better understanding of the Earth's climate history.

fact_checked_segment: The amount of energy used to construct solar and wind facilities is greater than they produce in their working lives.
comment_by_fact-checker: Numbers for “Energy Return on Investment” (EROI) are all over the place, but a nice summary with references to supporting information was produced for Scientific American by Mason Inman for the April 2013 edition of Scientific American. Mason estimated that wind returns about 20 times the energy input and solar around 6 times their energy input. While these numbers do depend on a range of assumptions, the idea that these ratios are less than one is wrong and not defensible. The construction of wind turbines and solar panels does result in some carbon dioxide emission but far less than would be emitted were that electricity generated using fossil fuels such as coal, gas, or oil. Therefore, if the alternative is fossil fuels, these technologies help avoid carbon dioxide emissions. It should be noted that Energy Return on Investment is likely to increase over time as the economy becomes more efficient and thus economic inputs to the production of energy technologies becomes less energy intensive
Label: No Fallacy
debunk:
Title: "Energy Efficiency of Solar and Wind Facilities"
Fact: Solar and wind facilities produce energy by harnessing natural resources like the sun and wind. While there is an energy cost involved in manufacturing and installing these facilities, studies have shown that the amount of energy they produce over their working lives is greater than the amount of energy used to construct them.
Myth: Some people believe that the amount of energy used to construct solar and wind facilities is greater than they produce in their working lives.
Fallacy: This myth is based on the logical fallacy of cherry-picking, as it selectively presents only part of the story. While it is true that there is an energy cost involved in manufacturing and installing solar and wind facilities, studies have shown that over their working lives, they produce significantly more energy than was used in their construction.
Fact: The energy efficiency of solar and wind facilities is a subject of ongoing research and debate, but the overwhelming majority of studies have shown that they produce more energy over their working lives than was used to construct them. Let's not spread misinformation about the energy efficiency of renewable energy technologies.

fact_checked_segment: “So it’s been a surprise to climate scientists that 2017 has been so remarkably warm — because the last El Niño ended a year ago.”
comment_by_fact-checker: The claim that this is “a surprise to climate scientists” is not correct. In December 2016, climate scientists at the UK’s Met Office Hadley Centre predicted that 2017 would be “another very warm year for global temperatures”. 2017 was forecast to be among the warmest on record, but not as warm as 2016, so what is happening is actually consistent with the prediction.
Label: No Fallacy
debunk:
Title: "2017 Global Temperature and El Niño"

Fact: The Earth's temperature is influenced by a complex array of factors, including natural climate cycles and human activities like burning fossil fuels. The El Niño-Southern Oscillation (ENSO) is a natural climate cycle that can influence global temperatures by warming or cooling the Pacific Ocean.
Myth: Some people believe that the fact that 2017 has been remarkably warm despite the end of the last El Niño is surprising to climate scientists.
Fallacy: This myth is not based on a logical fallacy, but it is misleading. While it is true that the end of the last El Niño was expected to lead to cooler temperatures in 2017, climate scientists are not surprised that temperatures have remained warm due to the ongoing influence of human-caused climate change.
Fact: While the end of the last El Niño was expected to lead to cooler temperatures in 2017, the ongoing influence of human-caused climate change means that temperatures have remained warm. Climate scientists have long recognized that human activities are contributing to a warming trend that is superimposed on natural climate cycles like ENSO. Let's not spread misinformation about the causes of global temperature trends.

fact_checked_segment: “[Those who signed the Paris Accord] cannot change Earth’s orbit and radiation released from the sun that drive climate”
comment_by_fact-checker: The problem we are dealing with here is not the radiation released from the sun, but with the amount of energy that remains in the Earth’s climate system. The amount of energy trapped in the climate system increases due to the presence of greenhouse gases in the atmosphere: rather than shooting the energy back into space, it is used to heat the climate system. Simple physical laws, that make that more greenhouse gases cause a warmer climate. NASA’s Earth Observatory has an extensive explanation.
Label: Red Herring
debunk:
Title: "The Paris Accord and Climate Change Drivers"
Fact: The Paris Accord is an international agreement aimed at reducing greenhouse gas emissions and limiting global warming to well below 2 degrees Celsius above pre-industrial levels. While the Accord cannot change the Earth's orbit or the radiation released from the sun, it is focused on addressing human activities that contribute to climate change, such as the burning of fossil fuels and deforestation.
Myth: Some people believe that the Paris Accord is irrelevant because it cannot change the Earth's orbit or the radiation released from the sun that drive climate.
Fallacy: This myth is based on the logical fallacy of a straw man argument, as it misrepresents the focus of the Paris Accord and presents an irrelevant point in order to distract from the more important point of addressing human activities that contribute to climate change. In reality, the Paris Accord is focused on reducing greenhouse gas emissions and limiting global warming, which are caused by human activities.
Fact: The Paris Accord is an important step in addressing the human activities that contribute to climate change. While it cannot change the Earth's orbit or the radiation released from the sun, it is focused on reducing greenhouse gas emissions and limiting global warming, which are caused by human activities. Let's not spread misinformation about the focus and importance of the Paris Accord.

fact_checked_segment: At one point, Smith showed a slide of two charts that he said demonstrated how the rate of sea-level rise does not equal the sharp spike in the consumption of fossil fuels.
comment_by_fact-checker: This statement is blatantly false: sea-level rise in the 20th century is faster than any time during the last 3000 years[1], while the present-day rate is already three times faster than the 20th-century rate[2]. [1] Kopp et al (2016). Temperature-Driven Global Sea-Level Variability in the Common Era, PNAS [2] Dangendorf et al (2017) Reassessment of 20th Century Global Mean Sea Level Rise, PNAS
Label: No Fallacy
debunk:
Title: "Sea-Level Rise and Fossil Fuels"
Fact: Sea-level rise is one of the impacts of climate change, caused by the melting of ice caps and glaciers and the thermal expansion of ocean water. The burning of fossil fuels, which release greenhouse gases like carbon dioxide into the atmosphere, is a major contributor to climate change.
Myth: Some people believe that the rate of sea-level rise does not match the sharp spike in the consumption of fossil fuels.
Fallacy: This myth is based on the logical fallacy of cherry-picking data, as it selectively presents only part of the story. While it is true that the specific rate of sea-level rise may not directly match the sharp spike in fossil fuel consumption, this does not negate the overall relationship between greenhouse gas emissions and climate change, including sea-level rise.
Fact: The burning of fossil fuels contributes to climate change, which in turn causes sea-level rise. While the specific rate of sea-level rise may be influenced by a variety of factors, the overall relationship between fossil fuel consumption and climate change is well-established. Let's not spread misinformation about the impacts of fossil fuels on the Earth's climate.

fact_checked_segment: “The changes in the amount of oxygen in the shells isn’t a reflection of changing temperatures – just a consequence of the fact that the amount of oxygen seen changes over time anyway.”
comment_by_fact-checker: It doesn’t just change over time anyway. Firstly, we are talking about the isotope ratio of oxygen, not the amount. Secondly, the authors show evidence that in some depositional settings this sort of “resetting” of temperatures could occur. By over-simplifying here the author of the article loses and obscures the original study.
Label: Cherry Picking
debunk:
Title: "Oxygen and Climate Change"
Fact: Changes in oxygen levels within shells can be used as a proxy for changes in ocean temperature over time. Scientists can analyze the oxygen isotopes in fossil shells to estimate the temperature of the surrounding water at the time the shell was formed.
Myth: Some people believe that changes in the amount of oxygen in shells are not a reflection of changing temperatures, but rather a consequence of natural changes over time.
Fallacy: This myth is based on the logical fallacy of ambiguity, as it uses ambiguous language to lead to a misleading conclusion. While it is true that oxygen levels in shells can change over time, the specific changes in oxygen isotopes that scientists use as a proxy for temperature are not simply the result of natural variability over time.
Fact: Changes in the amount of oxygen in shells can be used as a proxy for changes in ocean temperature over time, based on specific changes in oxygen isotopes. This is an important tool for understanding how the Earth's climate has changed in the past and how it may change in the future. Let's not spread misinformation about the role of oxygen in understanding climate change.

fact_checked_segment: “[Sea ice] also helps regulate the planet’s temperature by influencing the circulation of the atmosphere and ocean. It can affect weather in the U.S.”
comment_by_fact-checker: There is currently no consensus in the scientific community about the magnitude of Arctic-lower-latitudes teleconnections compared to other teleconnections (e.g. from the tropics). This statement has to be taken with caution.
Label: False Authority
debunk:
Title: "The Importance of Sea Ice"
Fact: Sea ice is frozen seawater that plays a critical role in regulating the Earth's climate. It helps to keep the planet cool by reflecting sunlight back into space, and it also influences the circulation of the atmosphere and ocean, which can affect weather patterns around the globe.
Myth: Some people believe that sea ice is unimportant and has no significant impact on the Earth's climate or weather patterns.
Fallacy: This myth is based on the logical fallacy of oversimplification, as it ignores the complex role that sea ice plays in regulating the Earth's climate and weather patterns. Sea ice is a critical component of the Earth's climate system and has far-reaching impacts on the planet's temperature, atmospheric circulation, and ocean currents.
Fact: Sea ice is a critical component of the Earth's climate system and plays a significant role in regulating the planet's temperature and weather patterns. It is important to recognize the role that sea ice plays in the climate system and to take steps to protect it from the impacts of climate change. Let's not spread misinformation about the importance of sea ice.

fact_checked_segment: “The extreme cycles of dry and wet weather appear to have been intensifying over the last three decades.”
comment_by_fact-checker: Yes, variability in California precipitation appears to have been higher in the past 3-4 decades than the previous decades, but it is not (and cannot be) clear that that the variability in precipitation is actually currently in the act of increasing. I say that it cannot be clear because it takes decades of data (say 2-3) to characterize the current “variability” of the climate. Based on my calculations, variability in annual precipitation totals increased considerably during the second half of the 1900s and then has remained at this relatively high level for the past couple decades, but has not clearly continued to increase. This latest swing from record dry to very wet in the last year is consistent with high variability, but it’s a single event and not necessarily indicative of a trend. There are some logical links, however, that support the inference that wild swings like the current one should be expected to become more likely. First, droughts are becoming increasingly impacted by warming temperatures. Even if precipitation behavior didn’t change at all, years with low precipitation would correspond to less and less water availability for humans and ecosystems. Second, current climate models project variability of California precipitation to increase in the future, with an increase in the frequency of years with very high precipitation totals becoming detectable sometime in the first half of this century, and an increase in the frequency of years with very low precipitation totals becoming detectable in the second half of this century*. It should always be remembered, however, that models have a tough time with California precipitation. California is right on the boundary between projections of drying to the south and wetting to the north. I personally believe the basic expectation that California precipitation should become more variable, but beyond that I don’t yet put much stock in what models have to say about the future of precipitation in California. So, variability has increased overall in the last century, and this is consistent with what models project to occur as a result of greenhouse-gas driven climate change. The increase in variability hasn’t been a monotonic trend, however, and it is not obvious from the data that the trend is continuing now as rapidly as it was in previous decades. This suggests that other low-frequency processes are also at play that influence decade-to-decade changes in the variability and magnitude of annual precipitation totals, making it particularly difficult to determine the degree to which this current event can be attributed to climate change. Nonetheless, California would be wise to prepare for more events like these. Berg and Hall (2015) Increased Interannual Precipitation Extremes over California under Climate Change, Journal of Climate
Label: Cherry Picking
debunk:
Title: "Intensifying Weather Patterns"
Fact: The Earth's climate is subject to natural cycles of dry and wet weather, which can be influenced by a variety of factors, including changes in ocean currents and atmospheric circulation patterns. In recent decades, however, there is evidence that these cycles have been intensifying, leading to more frequent and extreme weather events.
Myth: Some people believe that there is no evidence to support the claim that weather patterns have been intensifying over the last three decades.
Fallacy: This myth is based on the logical fallacy of ignoring evidence, as there is a growing body of scientific research that supports the claim that weather patterns have been intensifying. This research is based on a variety of sources, including satellite data, weather observations, and climate models.
Fact: The claim that weather patterns have been intensifying over the last three decades is supported by a growing body of scientific research. This intensification can have significant impacts on communities and ecosystems around the world, highlighting the importance of addressing climate change. Let's not spread misinformation about the evidence of intensifying weather patterns.

fact_checked_segment: One of the main areas of contention is the existence of two strange climate episodes known as The Medieval Warm Period (MWP) and the Little Ice Age. The MWP lasted from about 950 to 1250AD, and temperature records appear to show it was even hotter than today
comment_by_fact-checker: These periods are now well understood to be, at best, regional phenomena rather than global-scale changes. Indeed, it is the broad global nature of the recently observed changes that make them unusual. The realisation of these being largely regional phenomena centred on the N. Atlantic region has led to a growing deprecation of these terms.
Label: Red Herring
debunk:
Title: "Understanding the Medieval Warm Period and the Little Ice Age"
Fact: The Medieval Warm Period (MWP) and the Little Ice Age were two climate episodes that occurred prior to the Industrial Revolution. The MWP lasted from about 950 to 1250 AD and was characterized by relatively warm temperatures in some parts of the world, while the Little Ice Age lasted from about 1300 to 1850 AD and was characterized by cooler temperatures in some parts of the world.
Myth: Some people believe that temperature records show that the MWP was even hotter than today, casting doubt on the idea that current climate change is primarily caused by human activities.
Fallacy: This myth is based on the logical fallacy of cherry-picking, as it selectively presents evidence that supports a particular view while ignoring other evidence that contradicts it. While it is true that some temperature records suggest that the MWP was warmer than today in some regions, other records suggest that it was not as warm as today in other regions. Moreover, the causes of the MWP and the Little Ice Age are not well understood and are likely to have been influenced by a range of factors.
Fact: The MWP and the Little Ice Age were two climate episodes that occurred prior to the Industrial Revolution and are not directly comparable to current climate change, which is primarily caused by human activities. While some temperature records suggest that the MWP was warmer than today in some regions, it is not accurate to suggest that this casts

fact_checked_segment: “Representatives from the Marshall Islands have been vocal about the need for strong global action on climate. President Hilda Heine has told reporters that longtime residents are leaving the Marshall Islands because climate change is threatening the nation’s existence.”
comment_by_fact-checker: This is an interesting rhetorical trick by Bjorn Lomborg. So far he has only supported the point that ‘as of today, the area of many Pacific islands have not decreased’. But this doesn’t mean that ‘the islands existence is not threatened’, notably in the future as sea level rise becomes more severe. So here, he is swapping a weak claim that he has supported for a much stronger one that he has not, a version of the red herring fallacy.
Label: No Fallacy
debunk:
Title: "Climate Change and the Marshall Islands"
Fact: The Marshall Islands is a nation of low-lying islands in the Pacific Ocean that is particularly vulnerable to the impacts of climate change, such as sea level rise and more intense storms. The nation's representatives have been vocal about the need for strong global action on climate change in order to protect the future of their country.
Myth: There is no myth presented in this statement.
Fact: President Hilda Heine of the Marshall Islands has stated that climate change is threatening the existence of the nation, and that longtime residents are leaving due to the impacts of climate change. This illustrates the urgent need for action on climate change, as it is already having devastating impacts on vulnerable communities around the world. Let's heed the calls of those who are most affected by climate change and take action to address this pressing global issue.

fact_checked_segment: [headline:] Climate Change ‘Heat Records’ Are a Huge Data Manipulation
comment_by_fact-checker: This is the biggest and most ludicrous claim of the article—the claim that will be read most and shared most on social media—and the article provides no evidence the data was manipulated.
Label: Evading the Burden of Proof
debunk:
Title: "Understanding Climate Change Heat Records"
Fact: Climate change is causing global temperatures to rise, leading to more frequent and intense heat waves. Heat records are measurements of temperature that exceed previous highs for a given location and time period.
Myth: Some people believe that climate change heat records are a result of data manipulation and not a true reflection of changing temperatures.
Fallacy: This myth is based on the logical fallacy of a false accusation, as it suggests that climate scientists are manipulating data to create false records of rising temperatures. In reality, heat records are based on accurate measurements of temperature and are a reflection of the real-world impacts of climate change.
Fact: Heat records are a legitimate and important way of tracking the impacts of climate change on global temperatures and human health. Attempts to discredit them as a result of data manipulation are unfounded and ignore the overwhelming evidence of rising temperatures caused by human activities. Let's not spread misinformation about the science of climate change.

fact_checked_segment: “Global warming is largely being driven by emissions from human activities, but a strong El Niño – a natural climate cycle – added to the heat in 2016.”
comment_by_fact-checker: Yes, as stated in the last IPCC report, human emissions of greenhouse gases have been the dominant driver of climate change since the mid-20th century. No other changes (such as the output of the Sun) can adequately explain the observed warming.
Label: No Fallacy
debunk:
Title: "Global Warming and Natural Climate Cycles"
Fact: Global warming refers to the long-term increase in the Earth's average surface temperature, largely due to emissions of greenhouse gases from human activities like burning fossil fuels and deforestation. This increase in temperature is causing significant changes in the Earth's climate, including more frequent and intense heatwaves, droughts, and extreme weather events.
Myth: Some people believe that a strong El Niño in 2016 was solely responsible for the increase in global temperatures that year, and that human activities are not a major driver of global warming.
Fallacy: This myth is based on the logical fallacy of a false equivalence, as it suggests that a natural climate cycle like El Niño is equivalent in importance to the long-term trend of global warming caused by human activities. In reality, while El Niño can contribute to short-term fluctuations in global temperatures, it does not negate the long-term trend of global warming caused by human activities.
Fact: While a strong El Niño in 2016 did contribute to the high global temperatures that year, it was not solely responsible for the long-term trend of global warming caused by human activities. Human activities continue to be the primary driver of global warming, and reducing emissions of greenhouse gases remains crucial for mitigating the impacts of climate change. Let's not spread misinformation about the drivers of global warming.

fact_checked_segment: “Policy makers who want to help the residents of the Marshall Islands today should look at improving the islands’ resilience”
comment_by_fact-checker: This is a classic technique in Lomborg’s articles: he focuses on one small aspect of climate change – here the Marshall Islands, other times maybe polar bears or heat-related human deaths – that i) he passes off as the main concern about global warming, and ii) that he can provide some seemingly contradictory information about… All the other consequences of global warming are conveniently set aside… Red herring.
Label: Red Herring
debunk:
Title: "Improving Resilience in the Marshall Islands"
Fact: The Marshall Islands are a low-lying island nation in the Pacific Ocean that are particularly vulnerable to the impacts of climate change, such as sea level rise and increased storm intensity. These impacts can cause flooding, erosion, and damage to infrastructure, homes, and livelihoods.
Opinion: Some policy makers believe that improving the resilience of the Marshall Islands is the most effective way to help its residents today.
Fact: Improving the resilience of the Marshall Islands involves implementing measures to help the islands adapt to the impacts of climate change, such as building seawalls, improving water management, and diversifying livelihoods. These measures can help to protect the islands and their residents from the immediate impacts of climate change.
Opinion: Focusing on resilience is an important step in helping the residents of the Marshall Islands today. However, it is also important to address the root causes of climate change and to work towards reducing greenhouse gas emissions in order to prevent further impacts in the future. Let's not forget the importance of both adaptation and mitigation in addressing the impacts of climate change in vulnerable communities like the Marshall Islands.

fact_checked_segment: “Unlike genuine pollutants, carbon dioxide (CO2) is an odorless, colorless gas. Every human being exhales about two pounds of CO2 a day, along with a similar amount of water vapor. CO2 is nontoxic to people and animals”
comment_by_fact-checker: Timothy Osborn, Professor, University of East Anglia, and Director of Research, Climatic Research Unit: This is a diversionary tactic: the concern about CO2 is not about its smell, its colour or its direct toxicity; instead it is about its effect on the Earth’s climate. So it is a strawman statement that may be easily demolished but not relevant to the concern about CO2 and climate change.
Label: Strawman
debunk:
Title: "Carbon Dioxide and Climate Change"
Fact: Carbon dioxide (CO2) is a natural component of the Earth's atmosphere and is produced by both natural and human activities. While it is true that CO2 is odorless and nontoxic to people and animals, it is also a greenhouse gas that can contribute to climate change.
Myth: Some people believe that the fact that CO2 is odorless, nontoxic, and produced by natural sources means that it is not a significant contributor to climate change.
Fallacy: This myth is based on the logical fallacy of a false analogy, as it assumes that because CO2 is a natural component of the atmosphere and is nontoxic, it cannot be a significant contributor to climate change. In reality, the fact that CO2 is natural and nontoxic does not diminish its significance as a greenhouse gas that can contribute to climate change.
Fact: While it is true that CO2 is odorless and nontoxic, it is also a greenhouse gas that can contribute to climate change. Human activities, such as burning fossil fuels, have increased the amount of CO2 in the atmosphere, leading to global warming and other impacts on the Earth's climate. Let's not spread misinformation about the role of CO2 in climate change.

fact_checked_segment: “There was, he said, an ‘inherent bias’ in scientific journals which predisposed them to publish ‘doom and gloom stories’.”
comment_by_fact-checker: The words “inherent bias” do not appear in my article. Rather, I refer to “publication bias”. In research, an “inherent bias” is one which is inextricably tied to the core nature of the phenomenon being studied and cannot, therefore, be eliminated by increasing the sample size or choosing a different estimator. “Publication bias”, on the other hand, refers to the general (across all of science) phenomenon by which studies presenting positive results – supporting the hypothesis being tested – are more likely to be published than those reporting negative results. This sometimes creates a situation where published studies may be systematically different from unpublished studies – for example, studies showing an impact of ocean acidification might be published more easily and in higher profile journals than studies showing no impact. However, I only allude to this possibility in the introduction; I do not asses it quantitatively (something that would, in fact, be very difficult to do). Finally, the words “doom and gloom” do not appear in my introduction.
Label: Strawman
debunk:
Title: "Scientific Journals and Bias"
Fact: Scientific journals are an important means of disseminating research findings and scientific knowledge to the wider scientific community and the general public. They have rigorous peer-review processes to ensure that the research they publish is of high quality and meets certain standards of scientific rigor.
Myth: Some people believe that scientific journals have an inherent bias that predisposes them to publish 'doom and gloom stories'.
Fallacy: This myth is based on the logical fallacy of a generalization, as it suggests that all scientific journals have a specific bias. Relative sea-level rise has a variety of components that give the rise a spatial signature. For example along the mid US Atlantic coast one-third of the rise is due to glacial isostatic adjustment with the remainder dominated by climatically driven sea-level rise. But in the Mississippi Delta the dominant driving force is subsidence. However, in the coming century these components will decrease in importance relative to climatically driven sea-level rise.
Label: False Cause
debunk:
Title: "Nuisance Flooding and Climate Change"

Myth: Some people believe that the increase in nuisance flooding is not related to climate change.

It is important to take action to address the root causes of climate change and to adapt to the impacts of a changing climate. Let's not spread misinformation about the relationship between climate change and nuisance flooding.

fact_checked_segment: “But as that upper layer warms up, the oxygen-rich waters are less likely to mix down into cooler layers of the ocean because the warm waters are less dense and do not sink as readily.”
comment_by_fact-checker: Enhanced stratification of the water column is indeed one mechanism that can explain the decrease in subsurface oxygen, notably in the tropics[1]. As the upper-layer of the ocean warms faster than the deeper layers, the temperature stratification increases, with the already-warm upper layer getting warmer. This enhanced thermal stratification acts as a barrier to vertical mixing, since warmer water is less dense (like when a low density fluid (e.g. oil) tops a high density fluid (e.g. water)). This stratification can prevent oxygen coming from the surface from reaching deeper layers where it gets depleted by biological activity (respiration). As climate change proceeds, the upper-ocean layer is also expected to become fresher (less salty) in the tropics as rainfall increase, further increasing the upper-ocean stratification[2]. [1] Behrenfeld et al (2006) Climate-driven trends in contemporary ocean productivity. Nature [2] Balaguru et al (2016) Global warming-induced upper-ocean freshening and the intensification of super typhoons. Nature Communications
Label: Strawman

fact_checked_segment: “the basic rule for staple cereal crops grown at optimal temperature is that for every degree of warming, yields decline by 10 percent. Some estimates run as high as 15 or even 17 percent. Which means that if the planet is five degrees warmer at the end of the century, we may have as many as 50 percent more people to feed and 50 percent less grain to give them.”
comment_by_fact-checker: These numbers stem from the results of controlled field sites (in, for example, the Philippines, India and Mexico) and refer to the impact of local temperature changes on yield, all else being equal. (Also, note that the major grain producing regions are in the midlatitudes, where the projected temperature increases are substantially greater than the projected global average temperature increase.) The projected changes in precipitation are sufficiently uncertain that it is not possible to quantitatively account for the impact of their changes, although the IPCC 2013 WG1 Report concludes: “In many mid-latitude and subtropical dry regions, mean precipitation will likely decrease, while in many mid-latitude wet regions, mean precipitation will likely increase under the RCP8.5 scenario.” (In IPCC lingo, “likely” is greater than 2/3 chance.) Finally, there is also a fertilization effect associated with increasing CO2, although studies have shown that the deleterious impact of increasing temperature far outweigh the impact of increased CO2.
Label: False Analogy

While past periods with high CO2 levels did not necessarily result in catastrophes, this does not mean that current concerns about CO2 and climate change are unfounded.

fact_checked_segment: “Here’s an unusual one from Guillet et al suggesting that there’s nothing new about wildly early or late grape harvests through the centuries
comment_by_fact-checker: The Guillet et al paper primarily uses wine grapes to look at the impact of the 1257 Samalas eruption (volcanic aerosols cool the climate, delaying grape maturation and harvest). I haven’t read the paper in the detail, but as far as I can tell they do not make any claims about recent warming or harvest trends. Contrary to the claim quoted above, our own work suggest that warming has significantly advanced wine grape harvests over western Europe1. We found, on average, that winegrape harvests have been occurring significantly earlier since 1980 (on average 10 days earlier than the 1600-1900 average). In fact, 2003 was the earliest harvest in the record by about a month. On a broader note, I want to point out that exceptional events in the paleoclimate record do not undermine the case for attributing recent warming to anthropogenic greenhouse gas emissions. We know there have been warm periods in the past, but we have quite a bit of significant independent evidence that recent warming can only be explained by invoking anthropogenic activities. [read the Dr Guillet’s comment below] 1- Cook & Wolkovich (2016) Climate change decouples drought from early wine grape harvests in France. Nature
